keyTakeAways: A heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris involved the theft of nine high-value historical artifacts from the Apollo Gallery, including a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace, and multiple pieces associated with Empress Eugénie.

The stolen items include royal jewelry gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and pieces crafted for Empress Eugénie, such as a diamond-encrusted brooch and a pearl diadem, all of which hold significant historical and cultural value.
The heist took place in just seven minutes and involved four thieves who broke into two high-security cases, leaving the scene on motorcycles.
One key item, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the site but was damaged during the theft.

Experts like Arthur Brand describe the theft as a 'national disaster' for France due to the cultural and historical importance of the items, which represent the nation’s royal heritage and are likely to be dismantled and melted for resale.
The stolen jewelry has uncertain provenance, with some pieces possibly linked to Marie Antoinette, though the craftsmanship aligns with early 19th-century Parisian artisans.
The emerald necklace and earrings were originally gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise and were preserved and later acquired by the Louvre in 2004 for 3.7 million euros.
The reliquary brooch, containing the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, was acquired by the Louvre in 2008 for 6.72 million euros and is a central part of the museum’s collection.
The theft has triggered widespread public concern and international attention, as these items are considered national treasures and symbols of French history.

namedEntities.name: Marie-Louise of Austria
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Napoleon’s second wife, who received the emerald necklace as a wedding gift, and whose descendants later passed down the jewelry.

namedEntities.name: Empress Eugénie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wife of Napoleon III, a prominent 19th-century figure known for her fashion and religious devotion, and owner of several royal artifacts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Multiple items—like the reliquary brooch and the pearl diadem—were created for or belonged to Eugénie, making her a central figure in the cultural value of the theft.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A jeweler who crafted the reliquary brooch for Empress Eugénie in 1855.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The brooch was personally created for Eugénie, linking it to a specific artisan and historical moment.

namedEntities.name: François-Régnault Nitot
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A jeweler who crafted the sapphire diadem and jewelry worn by queens, including Hortense de Beauharnais.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The craftsmanship and origin of the sapphire diadem are attributed to this jeweler, adding historical authenticity.

namedEntities.name: Alexandre-Gabriel Lemonnier
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A jeweler who crafted the pearl diadem for Empress Eugénie in 1853.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The pearl diadem is one of the stolen pieces and was made by this artisan, reinforcing the craftsmanship link to Eugénie’s era.

namedEntities.name: François Kramer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A jeweler who crafted the original diamond belt worn by Eugénie and later transformed into a brooch.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The transformation of the belt into a brooch is tied to this jeweler and the historical context of Empress Eugénie’s court life.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A jeweler who bought the bow brooch from Caroline Astor in 1887.

namedEntities.name: Caroline Astor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A New York socialite who acquired the bow brooch in 1887 and later sold it to the Louvre in 2008.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a heist that occurred on Sunday, October 20, 2025, four thieves broke into the Apollo Gallery of the Louvre Museum in Paris, stealing nine historically significant royal artifacts within just seven minutes. Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces belonging to Empress Eugénie, including a reliquary brooch and a pearl diadem. The emerald necklace and earrings were purchased by the Louvre in 2004 for €3.7 million, while the bow brooch was acquired in 2008 for €6.72 million. One of the key items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged during the heist. Experts like Arthur Brand describe the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the immense cultural and historical value of these pieces, which are likely to be dismantled and melted for resale. The event has triggered widespread public concern and international attention, highlighting the fragility of cultural heritage and the threat posed by theft to national identity.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
